pr_title: Hive ACID row-level insert and delete

timeline.bodyText: I like this helper function, and the order and economy it brings to the tests I've added.  If there is no objection, I'll follow this PR with a PR that makes no semantic change but updates the previously existing tests to use this helper function.
timeline.author: djsstarburst

replies.bodyText:
Consumer testRunner

instead of putting the test in a lambda (which has some drawbacks), you can use t-w-r like we do in other tests --
https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/fbd4ca7f6ca1326a077fd06cd33b687cbfe17cf2/presto-postgresql/src/test/java/io/prestosql/plugin/postgresql/TestPostgreSqlTypeMapping.java#L414
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: I see your point, @findepi.  However, what I like about the lambda formulation is that it doesn't dictate the form of the CREATE TABLE statement; it just supplies the temporary table name.  In the tests I wrote, the CREATE TABLE statements vary over a pretty wide range, and don't always fit into the formulation (bucketed | unbucketed) X (partitioned | unpartioned)
replies.author: djsstarburst

timeline.bodyText: static import
timeline.author: losipiuk

timeline.bodyText: nit: static import
timeline.author: losipiuk

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if we should sometimes decide to drop all statistics after insert/delete. E.g. if the ratio of number of inserted rows to table size is large. Is there a place where we can track how many rows were added/deleted to the table since table was last analyzed. (I do not expect this to be addressed in this PR, just something to think of).
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: It's a good question, @losipiuk.  This PR does I believe get the table and partition row counts right in the case of deletion, but the Hive issues tracker shows lots of issues in which the statistics got out-of-sync with the material table.  The response in the tickets is to analyze the table.
replies.author: djsstarburst

timeline.bodyText: nit: static import isTransactionalTable
timeline.author: losipiuk

timeline.bodyText: nit: we can pass empty statistics here so there is just one place where statistics for partition are update. It is happening below anyway, right?
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: AFAICT they are distinct cases.  The case above handles empty partitions when the session property says to create empty files.  Maybe there is a straightforward way to combine them, but I don't see it.
replies.author: djsstarburst

timeline.bodyText:
WriteId makes sense in context of single table, right? If multiple tables are modified in single Hive transactions those operations would have different writeIds attached.
I guess this is fine to have it in AcidTransaction class as Presto originated Hive transaction spans only single modification in Hive for single table, but it would be nice to have a comment here to state that.
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: An excellent point, @losipiuk, and one I've worried about but haven't solved.  When we support multiple operations in a transaction, we'll need to separate the ACID operation and a writeId for a particular table from the notion of a transaction.
replies.author: djsstarburst

Unfortunately, using ImmutableMap.Builder doesn't work here, because it doesn't permit duplicate keys, and the putAll() call will add the existing NUM_ROWS.
Your ordering and naming suggestions are good ones, and I've adopted those.

timeline.bodyText:
Shouldn't ThriftHiveMetastoreClient which is the deepest layer  only do simple transalation between Presto object model and Hive-metastore-thrift object model.
Here we are calling out to getValidWriteIds. Maybe instead we should pass valid write ids as parameter?
possibly this is fine but I want to double check on thinking here.
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: I'll need to think about this.  The reason did it this way was to match Hive.

timeline.bodyText: Should we add checks that statmentId is at most 2^16 and bucketId is at most 2^12 (I guess that is the limit based on 0xfff above)

timeline.bodyText: why not always take writeId from transaction?
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: I wanted to leave open the possibility that the OrcFileWriter wrote on behalf of a range of writeids.  This will be needed when we support multi-operation transactions.

timeline.message:
Hive ACID row-level insert and delete

This commit adds support for row-level insert and delete for Hive ACID tables,
and product tests that verify that row-level insert (and delete where allowed)
are working correctly for this test matrix:

(partitioned | unpartitioned) X
(bucketed | unbucketed) X
(normal | insert-only) X
(original files | non-original files) X
(Presto inserts | Hive inserts) X
(first insert | subsequent inserts) X
(Presto deletes | Hive deletes) X
(first delete | subsequent deletes) X
(Hive selects to verify | Presto selects to verify)

The tests also verify that metadata delete still works correctly for non-ACID
tables, and that row-level delete is always used for ACID tables. Hive ACID
insert and delete make metastore updates using the delayed commit paradigm
provided by SemiTransactionalHiveMetastore.

ACID insert and delete need four Hive metastore methods not previously
used, and this commit adds the plumbing through the many metastore layers
for those methods.

Records to be deleted flow through HiveUpdatablePageSource, which feeds an OrcWriter
the three columns - - originalTransaction, bucketId, rowId - - that identify an
ACID row to be deleted. The writer builds the ACID delete_delta bucket, adding
the Orc ACID operation column specifying delete and the currentTransaction column
to each row.

A complete delete scan will in general read many Orc files from earlier transactions.
The delete implementation will create a HiveUpdatablePageSource for each file.
Each will write a delete_delta file, distinguished by different statementIds.
These delete_delta bucket files and directories will be combined by the Hive
ACID compactor as the accumulate.

ACID insert is simpler than delete - - it just adds the 5 ACID columns needed
to make insertion transactional, and creates delta directories to hold bucket files.

Hive ACID row-level insert and delete

This commit adds support for row-level insert and delete for Hive ACID tables,
and product tests that verify that row-level insert (and delete where allowed)
are working correctly for this test matrix:

(partitioned | unpartitioned) X
(bucketed | unbucketed) X
(normal | insert-only) X
(original files | non-original files) X
(Presto inserts | Hive inserts) X
(first insert | subsequent inserts) X
(Presto deletes | Hive deletes) X
(first delete | subsequent deletes) X
(Hive selects to verify | Presto selects to verify)

The tests also verify that metadata delete still works correctly for non-ACID
tables, and that row-level delete is always used for ACID tables. Hive ACID
insert and delete make metastore updates using the delayed commit paradigm
provided by SemiTransactionalHiveMetastore.

ACID insert and delete need four Hive metastore methods not previously
used, and this commit adds the plumbing through the many metastore layers
for those methods.

Records to be deleted flow through HiveUpdatablePageSource, which feeds an OrcWriter
the three columns - - originalTransaction, bucketId, rowId - - that identify an
ACID row to be deleted. The writer builds the ACID delete_delta bucket, adding
the Orc ACID operation column specifying delete and the currentTransaction column
to each row.

A complete delete scan will in general read many Orc files from earlier transactions.
The delete implementation will create a HiveUpdatablePageSource for each file.
Each will write a delete_delta file, distinguished by different statementIds.
These delete_delta bucket files and directories will be combined by the Hive
ACID compactor as the accumulate.

ACID insert is simpler than delete - - it just adds the 5 ACID columns needed
to make insertion transactional, and creates delta directories to hold bucket files.

timeline.bodyText: Should this be moved before invoking the delegate?
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText:
What's the reason to call commit within cleanupQuery?
what if

query is part of a longer transaction (we seem to commit everything too early)
query is cancelled/aborted/etc -- it seems we commit instead of rolling back

please help me understand
cc @losipiuk
timeline.author: findepi
